If an integrable function has zero integral on all closed sets, then it is zero
almost everwhere.

name: MeasureTheory.ae_eq_zero_of_forall_set_integral_isClosed_eq_zero
docString:
If an integrable function has zero integral on all closed sets, then it is zero
almost everwhere.

For any measurable space with a topology and a bounded continuous function, the Lebesgue integral of the function with respect to the zero measure is zero.

type:
∀ {Ω : Type u_1} [inst : MeasurableSpace Ω] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Ω] (f : BoundedContinuousFunction Ω NNReal),
  MeasureTheory.FiniteMeasure.testAgainstNN 0 f = 0
name: MeasureTheory.FiniteMeasure.zero_testAgainstNN_apply
docString: For any measurable space with a topology and a bounded continuous function, the Lebesgue integral of the function with respect to the zero measure is zero.

This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `ℂ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] (f : ℂ → E) (c : ℂ),
  (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z) = 0
name: circleIntegral.integral_radius_zero
docString: This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `ℂ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ℂ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ℂ E H}
  [inst_5 : ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless I] {M : Type u_4} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_10 : PreconnectedSpace M] {f : M → F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf ℂ F) f → ∀ (a b : M), f a = f b
name: MDifferentiable.apply_eq_of_compactSpace
docString: A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant.

If a complex differentiable function on an open rectangle is continuous on the closed rectangle, then the integral of the function over the boundary of the rectangle equals zero.

type:
∀ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] (f : ℂ → E)
  (z w : ℂ),
  ContinuousOn f (Set.uIcc z.re w.re ×ℂ Set.uIcc z.im w.im) →
    DifferentiableOn ℂ f (Set.Ioo (min z.re w.re) (max z.re w.re) ×ℂ Set.Ioo (min z.im w.im) (max z.im w.im)) →
      (((∫ (x : ℝ) in z.re..w.re, f (↑x + ↑z.im * Complex.I)) - ∫ (x : ℝ) in z.re..w.re, f (↑x + ↑w.im * Complex.I)) +
            Complex.I • ∫ (y : ℝ) in z.im..w.im, f (↑w.re + ↑y * Complex.I)) -
          Complex.I • ∫ (y : ℝ) in z.im..w.im, f (↑z.re + ↑y * Complex.I) =
        0
name: Complex.integral_boundary_rect_eq_zero_of_continuousOn_of_differentiableOn
docString: If a complex differentiable function on an open rectangle is continuous on the closed rectangle, then the integral of the function over the boundary of the rectangle equals zero.

This theorem states that if a function `f` is locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real manifold, and if the integral of `f` multiplied by any smooth function that has compact support within `U` is zero, then the function `f` equals zero almost everywhere in `U`. Here, "almost everywhere" means that the set of points where the function does not equal zero has a measure of zero. The smooth function with compact support is differentiable to any order and is zero outside a compact set. The condition about the integral being zero effectively ensures that `f` and the smooth function are orthogonal in terms of the L^2 inner product, which is the integral of their product.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : FiniteDimensional ℝ E]
  {F : Type u_2} [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ℝ F] [inst_5 : CompleteSpace F]
  [inst_6 : MeasurableSpace E] [inst_7 : BorelSpace E] {f : E → F} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure E} {U : Set E},
  IsOpen U →
    MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrableOn f U μ →
      (∀ (g : E → ℝ), ContDiff ℝ ⊤ g → HasCompactSupport g → tsupport g ⊆ U → ∫ (x : E), g x • f x ∂μ = 0) →
        ∀ᵐ (x : E) ∂μ, x ∈ U → f x = 0
name: IsOpen.ae_eq_zero_of_integral_contDiff_smul_eq_zero
docString: This theorem states that if a function `f` is locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real manifold, and if the integral of `f` multiplied by any smooth function that has compact support within `U` is zero, then the function `f` equals zero almost everywhere in `U`. Here, "almost everywhere" means that the set of points where the function does not equal zero has a measure of zero. The smooth function with compact support is differentiable to any order and is zero outside a compact set. The condition about the integral being zero effectively ensures that `f` and the smooth function are orthogonal in terms of the L^2 inner product, which is the integral of their product.

If a locally integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space,
then it is zero almost everwhere.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {β : Type u_3}
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_4 : MeasurableSpace β] [inst_5 : BorelSpace β] [inst_6 : SigmaCompactSpace β]
  [inst_7 : T2Space β] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure β} {f : β → E},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f →
    (∀ (s : Set β), IsCompact s → ∫ (x : β) in s, f x ∂μ = 0) → f =ᶠ[MeasureTheory.Measure.ae μ] 0
name: MeasureTheory.ae_eq_zero_of_forall_set_integral_isCompact_eq_zero'
docString:
If a locally integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space,
then it is zero almost everwhere.

If an integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space, then
it is zero almost everwhere.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {β : Type u_3}
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_4 : MeasurableSpace β] [inst_5 : BorelSpace β] [inst_6 : SigmaCompactSpace β]
  [inst_7 : T2Space β] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure β} {f : β → E},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f →
    (∀ (s : Set β), IsCompact s → ∫ (x : β) in s, f x ∂μ = 0) → f =ᶠ[MeasureTheory.Measure.ae μ] 0
name: MeasureTheory.ae_eq_zero_of_forall_set_integral_isCompact_eq_zero
docString:
If an integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space, then
it is zero almost everwhere.

A holomorphic function on a compact complex manifold is locally constant.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ℂ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ℂ E H}
  [inst_5 : ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless I] {M : Type u_4} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] {f : M → F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf ℂ F) f → IsLocallyConstant f
name: MDifferentiable.isLocallyConstant
docString: A holomorphic function on a compact complex manifold is locally constant.

Ring homomorphisms map zero to zero.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} {β : Type u_3} {x : NonAssocSemiring α} {x_1 : NonAssocSemiring β} (f : α →+* β), f 0 = 0
name: RingHom.map_zero
docString: Ring homomorphisms map zero to zero.

Integral of a simple function whose codomain is `ℝ≥0∞`.

type: {α : Type u_1} → {_m : MeasurableSpace α} → MeasureTheory.SimpleFunc α ENNReal → MeasureTheory.Measure α → ENNReal
name: MeasureTheory.SimpleFunc.lintegral
docString: Integral of a simple function whose codomain is `ℝ≥0∞`.

The integrals of thickened indicators of a closed set against a finite measure tend to the
measure of the closed set if the thickening radii tend to zero.

type:
∀ {Ω : Type u_2} [inst : MeasurableSpace Ω] [inst_1 : PseudoEMetricSpace Ω] [inst_2 : OpensMeasurableSpace Ω]
  (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure Ω) [inst_3 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasure μ] {F : Set Ω},
  IsClosed F →
    ∀ {δs : ℕ → ℝ} (δs_pos : ∀ (n : ℕ), 0 < δs n),
      Filter.Tendsto δs Filter.atTop (nhds 0) →
        Filter.Tendsto (fun n => ∫⁻ (ω : Ω), ↑((thickenedIndicator (_ : 0 < δs n) F) ω) ∂μ) Filter.atTop (nhds (↑↑μ F))
name: MeasureTheory.tendsto_lintegral_thickenedIndicator_of_isClosed
docString:
The integrals of thickened indicators of a closed set against a finite measure tend to the
measure of the closed set if the thickening radii tend to zero.

On an empty space, bounded continuous functions are at distance 0.

type:
∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : PseudoMetricSpace β]
  {f g : BoundedContinuousFunction α β} [inst_2 : IsEmpty α], dist f g = 0
name: BoundedContinuousFunction.dist_zero_of_empty
docString: On an empty space, bounded continuous functions are at distance 0.

Any descent of the zero morphism is homotopic to zero.

type:
{C : Type u} →
  [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{v, u} C] →
    [inst_1 : CategoryTheory.Abelian C] →
      {Y Z : C} →
        {I : CategoryTheory.InjectiveResolution Y} →
          {J : CategoryTheory.InjectiveResolution Z} →
            (f : I.cocomplex ⟶ J.cocomplex) → CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.comp I.ι f = 0 → Homotopy f 0
name: CategoryTheory.InjectiveResolution.descHomotopyZero
docString: Any descent of the zero morphism is homotopic to zero.

If a locally integrable function `f` on a finite-dimensional real manifold has zero integral
when multiplied by any smooth compactly supported function, then `f` vanishes almost everywhere.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : FiniteDimensional ℝ E]
  {F : Type u_2} [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ℝ F] [inst_5 : CompleteSpace F] {H : Type u_3}
  [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace H] (I : ModelWithCorners ℝ E H) {M : Type u_4} [inst_7 : TopologicalSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_10 : MeasurableSpace M]
  [inst_11 : BorelSpace M] [inst_12 : SigmaCompactSpace M] [inst_13 : T2Space M] {f : M → F}
  {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure M},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f →
    (∀ (g : M → ℝ), Smooth I (modelWithCornersSelf ℝ ℝ) g → HasCompactSupport g → ∫ (x : M), g x • f x ∂μ = 0) →
      ∀ᵐ (x : M) ∂μ, f x = 0
name: ae_eq_zero_of_integral_smooth_smul_eq_zero
docString:
If a locally integrable function `f` on a finite-dimensional real manifold has zero integral
when multiplied by any smooth compactly supported function, then `f` vanishes almost everywhere.

A differentiable function maps sets of measure zero to sets of measure zero.

name: MeasureTheory.addHaar_image_eq_zero_of_differentiableOn_of_addHaar_eq_zero
docString: A differentiable function maps sets of measure zero to sets of measure zero.

If a function `f` locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real
manifold has zero integral when multiplied by any smooth function compactly supported
in `U`, then `f` vanishes almost everywhere in `U`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : FiniteDimensional ℝ E]
  {F : Type u_2} [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ℝ F] [inst_5 : CompleteSpace F] {H : Type u_3}
  [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace H] (I : ModelWithCorners ℝ E H) {M : Type u_4} [inst_7 : TopologicalSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_10 : MeasurableSpace M]
  [inst_11 : BorelSpace M] [inst_12 : T2Space M] {f : M → F} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure M} {U : Set M},
  IsOpen U →
    IsSigmaCompact U →
      MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrableOn f U →
        (∀ (g : M → ℝ),
            Smooth I (modelWithCornersSelf ℝ ℝ) g →
              HasCompactSupport g → tsupport g ⊆ U → ∫ (x : M), g x • f x ∂μ = 0) →
          ∀ᵐ (x : M) ∂μ, x ∈ U → f x = 0
name: IsOpen.ae_eq_zero_of_integral_smooth_smul_eq_zero'
docString:
If a function `f` locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real
manifold has zero integral when multiplied by any smooth function compactly supported
in `U`, then `f` vanishes almost everywhere in `U`.

In an integral domain, a sum indexed by a nontrivial homomorphism from a finite group is zero.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {G : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : Group G] [inst_3 : Fintype G]
  (f : G →* R), f ≠ 1 → (Finset.sum Finset.univ fun g => f g) = 0
name: sum_hom_units_eq_zero
docString: In an integral domain, a sum indexed by a nontrivial homomorphism from a finite group is zero.

If a function `f` locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real
manifold has zero integral when multiplied by any smooth function compactly supported
in an open set `U`, then `f` vanishes almost everywhere in `U`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : FiniteDimensional ℝ E]
  {F : Type u_2} [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ℝ F] [inst_5 : CompleteSpace F]
  [inst_6 : MeasurableSpace E] [inst_7 : BorelSpace E] {f : E → F} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure E} {U : Set E},
  IsOpen U →
    MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrableOn f U →
      (∀ (g : E → ℝ), ContDiff ℝ ⊤ g → HasCompactSupport g → tsupport g ⊆ U → ∫ (x : E), g x • f x ∂μ = 0) →
        ∀ᵐ (x : E) ∂μ, x ∈ U → f x = 0
name: IsOpen.ae_eq_zero_of_integral_contDiff_smul_eq_zero
docString:
If a function `f` locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real
manifold has zero integral when multiplied by any smooth function compactly supported
in an open set `U`, then `f` vanishes almost everywhere in `U`.

If `f : ℂ → E` is continuous on the closed annulus `r ≤ ‖z - c‖ ≤ R`, `0 < r ≤ R`,
and is complex differentiable at all but countably many points of its interior,
then the integrals of `f z / (z - c)` (formally, `(z - c)⁻¹ • f z`)
over the circles `‖z - c‖ = r` and `‖z - c‖ = R` are equal to each other.

type:
∀ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {c : ℂ} {r R : ℝ},
  0 < r →
    r ≤ R →
      ∀ {f : ℂ → E} {s : Set ℂ},
        Set.Countable s →
          ContinuousOn f (Metric.closedBall c R \ Metric.ball c r) →
            (∀ z ∈ (Metric.ball c R \ Metric.closedBall c r) \ s, DifferentiableAt ℂ f z) →
              (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, R), (z - c)⁻¹ • f z) = ∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, r), (z - c)⁻¹ • f z
name: Complex.circleIntegral_sub_center_inv_smul_eq_of_differentiable_on_annulus_off_countable
docString:
If `f : ℂ → E` is continuous on the closed annulus `r ≤ ‖z - c‖ ≤ R`, `0 < r ≤ R`,
and is complex differentiable at all but countably many points of its interior,
then the integrals of `f z / (z - c)` (formally, `(z - c)⁻¹ • f z`)
over the circles `‖z - c‖ = r` and `‖z - c‖ = R` are equal to each other.

A Lebesgue Integral from -∞ to y can be expressed as the sum of one from -∞ to 0 and 0 to x

type:
∀ {y z : ℝ} (f : ℝ → ENNReal),
  z ≤ y → ∫⁻ (x : ℝ) in Set.Iic y, f x = (∫⁻ (x : ℝ) in Set.Iio z, f x) + ∫⁻ (x : ℝ) in Set.Icc z y, f x
name: lintegral_Iic_eq_lintegral_Iio_add_Icc
docString: A Lebesgue Integral from -∞ to y can be expressed as the sum of one from -∞ to 0 and 0 to x

A product of ideals in an integral domain is zero if and only if one of the terms is zero.

type: ∀ {R : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] {s : Multiset (Ideal R)}, Multiset.prod s = ⊥ ↔ ⊥ ∈ s
name: Ideal.multiset_prod_eq_bot
docString: A product of ideals in an integral domain is zero if and only if one of the terms is zero.

If the zero function is surjective, the codomain is trivial.

type: (α : Type u_4) → {β : Type u_5} → [inst : Zero β] → Function.Surjective 0 → Unique β
name: uniqueOfSurjectiveZero
docString: If the zero function is surjective, the codomain is trivial.

In an integral domain, a sum indexed by a homomorphism from a finite group is zero,
unless the homomorphism is trivial, in which case the sum is equal to the cardinality of the group.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {G : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : Group G] [inst_3 : Fintype G]
  (f : G →* R) [inst_4 : Decidable (f = 1)],
  (Finset.sum Finset.univ fun g => f g) = ↑(if f = 1 then Fintype.card G else 0)
name: sum_hom_units
docString:
In an integral domain, a sum indexed by a homomorphism from a finite group is zero,
unless the homomorphism is trivial, in which case the sum is equal to the cardinality of the group.
